newsitem.title: BULGARIA: BULGARIAN POLICE CRACK DOWN ON OPPOSITION PROTEST.
newsitem.headline: BULGARIAN POLICE CRACK DOWN ON OPPOSITION PROTEST.

text.p: Bulgarian riot police put an end to an opposition siege of parliament early on Saturday, firing blank cartridges and using clubs to beat a path for trapped deputies from the ruling Socialist party.
Police cleared a path to buses parked outside the darkened parliament building, and deputies left under a hail of stones thrown by opposition protesters.

They then turned their clubs on protesters who had been keeping vigil outside after attacking parliament on Friday in Bulgaria's worst political violence since the overthrow of one-party rule in 1989.
Police told deputies to lie down in the buses as they moved off, their windows smashed by stones.
Deputies of the opposition Union of Democratic Forces remained in the building. They have sworn to stay until their demand for a general election is met.
Bulgarian President Zhelyu Zhelev said he would not ask the ex-communist ruling party to form a new government on Saturday as expected because of the protests.

"Under these conditions, tomorrow I will not give a mandate for formation of a new government," Zhelev, who is normally a figurehead and has less than two weeks left in office, said on national television after visiting parliament.

He said he sympathised with the protesters but could not condone violence. "I back the protests of the people who have been driven to this humiliating state. In this way they are demonstrating their dignity," he said.
Zhelev had been expected on Saturday to summon Interior Minister Nikolai Dobrev, the Socialists' nominee for prime minister, to give him a mandate to form a new government.
Dobrev met president-elect Petar Stoyanov in parliament and Stoyanov said they had agreed to hold all-party talks.
"We both share the same opinion, that the most important is the interests of Bulgaria and talks between the political forces should start," Stoyanov said.
The demonstration started with a human chain of students around parliament. Protesters tried to attack former Socialist interior minister Lyubomir Nachev as he left the building.
Opposition deputies walked out after the Socialists refused to vote on a motion calling for early elections. The vote took place as clouds of teargas billowed into the building.
The demonstrators broke windows in the parliament and smashed and overturned cars which deputies had parked outside.
Some security forces chatted to protesters and expressed sympathy for their cause. "We are part of these people but I have to follow orders," said one policeman inside parliament.
Ivan Kostov, leader of the main opposition Union of Democratic Forces, called for a general strike and campaign of civil disobedience.
"After this clash and this lack of understanding, we believe there is no possibility for us to stay and keep on working in this parliament," he said.

Stoyanov -- an opposition figure whose election two months ago marked the collapse of public support for the Socialists -- was overcome by teargas while trying to calm the crowds through a loudspeaker. He was taken away by bodyguards.
Some 25 injured demonstrators and four police were treated in hospital.
Voters delivered a powerful no-confidence vote to the Socialist government two months ago by electing Stoyanov as president with 60 percent of votes.

Liquidity problems among the country's poorly supervised banks last year led to 14 being placed in receivership. A flight into dollars has pushed the lev from 70 to the dollar to 645 in a year. Annual inflation for 1996 hit 310.8 percent, the second largest rise since Bulgaria began market reform in 1990.

As soon as parliament approves a new cabinet the International Monetary Fund plans to negotiate implementation of a tough fixed exchange regime as a last resort to restore confidence in the crumbling economy.
